[1] 
   
 Denault, J. 
  [Translation]: This is an application for judicial review of a decision by the Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board ("the Refugee Division") on August 27, 1998 dismissing the refugee status claim of the applicants, who are originally from Bangladesh.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[2] 
  The applicants feared persecution in Bangladesh because of the political and social activities of the principal claimant ("the claimant"). In March 1989 the claimant became a member of the  
 Jatiya Party Bhandaria Thana Branch of Pirojpur District 
 . He was elected a member of the executive committee in January 1993 and became treasurer in January 1994. The applicant was beaten twice by supporters of the  
 Bangladesh Nationalist Party 
  ("BNP") when he was attending demonstrations. The latter attacked his business on one occasion and also vandalized his house. The applicant was also attacked twice by supporters of the fundamentalist organization  
 Jamaat-e-Islami 
 . The police arrested and beat the applicant on two occasions. On each occasion the applicant had to pay a bribe in order to be released.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[3] 
  Relying on various omissions, contradictions and inconsistencies, the Refugee Division dismissed the testimony of the principal claimant, which appeared to them to be [TRANSLATION] "an entire fabrication". The panel also found the allegations of the claimant that he was active in the  
 Jatiya 
  Party to be less than credible. The applicant was even found to lack credibility on the fact that he belonged to a political party or had been sought by the Bangladeshi police.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[4] 
  The applicants argued that the members of the Refugee Division made an error of law when they did not take into account a psychological expert opinion concluding that there was a severe post-traumatic stress disorder, and secondly, the specific documentary evidence of the applicant, namely letters setting out his social commitment regarding the oppression of women (P-8, p. 362 of the plaintiff's record), his membership in the  
 Jatiya 
  Party, in which he was even elected treasurer of one of the divisions (P-9, p. 364), and finally a letter from his counsel in Bangladesh describing his problems with the police (arrests, torture and bribes).  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[5] 
  The applicants further submitted that the Refugee Division also erred in concluding, first, that there was [TRANSLATION] "an absence of the minimum basis for these claims under s. 69.1(9.1) of the  
 Immigration Act 
 ", and second, without providing any reasons for this conclusion.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[6] 
  The respondent's response to the applicants' arguments comes down to the following proposition: assuming that the Refugee Division did not believe the principal applicant, it was not unreasonable to attach no evidentiary value to the psychological report and to conclude that there was an absence of minimum basis.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[7] 
  As I indicated at the close of the hearing of this matter, it is a case in which the court's intervention is warranted.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[8] 
  In my opinion the panel was wrong to conclude that the principal claimant was not credible without taking into account and without discussing the content of the psychological report which found severe post-traumatic stress disorder and the applicant's difficulties relating the traumatizing events he had experienced, except for negatively arriving at the conclusion that these were facts he had not indicated in his personal information form.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[9] 
  The panel further erred in concluding that the principal claimant was not credible as to his political commitment to the  
 Jatiya 
  party and the fact that he was sought by the police, when independent evidence relating specifically to the applicant corroborated his testimony on this point. The panel did not say a word about this evidence, which not only corroborated important aspects of his claim but at the very least supported the credibility of his testimony. )See to the same effect  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (T.D.).)  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[10] 
  The application for judicial review is allowed. The matter is referred back to the Board for re-hearing and reconsideration by a panel of different members. The case raises no question of general importance.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 Application allowed.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 Editor: Angela E. McKay/saf  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

legal_issues: Standard of review for administrative decisions regarding refugee status.
Sufficiency of evidence required to establish a well-founded fear of persecution.
Proper consideration of expert psychological evidence in assessing credibility of a claimant.
Weight to be given to corroborating evidence in assessing credibility.
Requirement for reasoned decision-making by administrative tribunals.
Whether a lack of credibility regarding specific details necessarily negates a claim of political activity or persecution.
Determination of whether a minimum evidentiary basis for a refugee claim exists.
factual_background: Applicants, originally from Bangladesh, claimed refugee status.
The claim was based on a fear of persecution due to the principal claimant's political and social activities.
The principal claimant became a member of the Jatiya Party Bhandaria Thana Branch in 1989.
The claimant held positions within the Jatiya Party, including member of the executive committee (1993) and treasurer (1994).
The claimant reported being physically assaulted on multiple occasions by supporters of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) and Jamaat-e-Islami.
The claimant's business and house were reportedly vandalized by BNP supporters.
The claimant alleged being arrested and physically abused by police on two occasions, requiring bribes for release.
The Refugee Division rejected the claimant's testimony, citing omissions, contradictions, and inconsistencies.
The Refugee Division questioned the claimant's involvement in the Jatiya Party and whether they were sought by Bangladeshi police.
A psychological report indicated severe post-traumatic stress disorder in the claimant.
Documentary evidence submitted included letters regarding social commitment, Jatiya Party membership, and issues with the police.

Applicants: The Refugee Division erred by not considering a psychological expert opinion diagnosing severe post-traumatic stress disorder.

The Refugee Division erred by not considering documentary evidence of the claimant’s social commitment (letters regarding oppression of women), membership and position (treasurer) in the Jatiya Party, and problems with the police (arrests, torture, bribes).
The Refugee Division erred in concluding there was an absence of a minimum basis for the claim under s. 69.1(9.1) of the Immigration Act without providing reasons.
The claimant experienced persecution in Bangladesh due to political and social activities, including beatings, attacks on his business and home, and arrests by police.
Respondents: If the Refugee Division did not believe the principal applicant, it was reasonable to assign no evidentiary value to the psychological report.
It was reasonable to conclude there was an absence of a minimum basis for the claim.

court_analysis: The Court allowed the application for judicial review because the Refugee Division erred in its assessment of the claimant’s credibility without properly considering a psychological report indicating severe post-traumatic stress disorder. The Court reasoned that the panel should have addressed the report’s findings regarding the claimant’s difficulty recounting traumatic events, rather than simply dismissing the testimony based on inconsistencies with the personal information form.

The Court found the Refugee Division also erred by discrediting the claimant’s testimony regarding his political involvement with the Jatiya Party and being sought by the police, despite the existence of independent evidence corroborating those claims. The panel’s failure to acknowledge or discuss this corroborating evidence was deemed a critical error.

The Court determined that the Refugee Division’s conclusion of a lack of a ‘minimum basis’ for the claim under s. 69.1(9.1) of the Immigration Act was also flawed due to the failure to consider relevant evidence and provide reasoning for that conclusion.

The Court emphasized that its intervention was warranted because the Refugee Division’s decision-making process was demonstrably flawed by its disregard for both the psychological assessment and the independent corroborating evidence, leading to an unreasonable outcome.
final_outcome: The matter is referred back to the Board for re-hearing and reconsideration by a panel of different members.
